question: Question_05_(a)
statement:
Consider the following problem involving Laplace's equation in an
annular region:

$u_{rr} + \frac1{r} u_r + \frac1{r^2}u_{\theta \theta} = 0,  \quad 1 < r < 2, \quad 0 < \theta < \pi/2.$

$u(1,\theta) = 0, \quad u(2,\theta) = 0, \quad u(r,0) = 0, \quad u(r,\pi/2) = f(r).$

Use the method of separation of variables to solve the problem when
$f(r) = \sin\left(\frac{2\pi}{\ln(2)}\ln(r)\right).$
sols:
To use the method of separation of variables, we write $u$ as

\begin{align*}u(r,\theta) = R(r ) \Theta (\theta) .  \,\end{align*}

We compute that

\begin{align*}u_r(r,\theta) = R'(r ) \Theta(\theta), \; u_{rr}(r,\theta) = R''(r ) \Theta (\theta),\end{align*}
and

\begin{align*}u_{\theta \theta}(r,\theta) = R(r ) \Theta'' (\theta) . \,\end{align*}
Substitute the above into our differential equation

\begin{align*}u_{rr} + \frac{1}{r} u_r + \frac{1}{r^2} u_{\theta \theta} = 0,\end{align*} we
get that

\begin{align*}R'' \Theta + \frac{1}{r} R' \Theta + \frac{1}{r^2} R \Theta'' = 0 .\end{align*}
Next, we would like to group all the $R$ terms onto one side and all the
$\Theta$ terms onto another, so divide the entire equation by $R \Theta$
to get

\begin{align*}\frac{R'' \Theta}{R \Theta} + \frac{1}{r} \frac{R' \Theta}{R \Theta} + \frac{1}{r^2} \frac{R \Theta''}{R \Theta} = 0\end{align*}
which gives

\begin{align*}\frac{R''}{R} + \frac{1}{r} \frac{R'}{R} + \frac{1}{r^2} \frac{\Theta''}{\Theta} = 0  .\end{align*}
To get rid of the factor of $\frac{1}{r^2}$ in the last term on the
left, we will multiply the equation by $r^2$ to get

\begin{align*}r^2 \frac{R''}{R} + r \frac{R'}{R} + \frac{\Theta''}{\Theta} = 0\end{align*}
which gives

\begin{align*}r^2 \frac{R''}{R} + r \frac{R'}{R} = -\frac{\Theta''}{\Theta} .\end{align*}
Here, $r$ and $\theta$ are independent of each other. However, the right
hand side of the equation is a function of $r$ while the right hand side
a function of $\theta$, so both sides of the equation must be equal to a
constant which we will denote $\mu$. In other words, we have

\begin{align*}r^2 \frac{R''}{R} + r \frac{R'}{R} = -\frac{\Theta''}{\Theta} = \mu .\end{align*}
This gives us two equations

\begin{align*}r^2 R'' + r R' = \mu R \;\; \text{and} \;\; - \Theta'' = \mu \Theta .\end{align*}

We will first solve the equation for $R$. Before we go ahead to do so,
we would like to figure out the boundary conditions for $R$. The
boundary conditions

\begin{align*}u(1,\theta) = 0 \;\; \text{and} \;\; u(2,\theta) = 0\end{align*} imply that

\begin{align*}R(1) \Theta(\theta) = 0 \;\; \text{and} \;\; R(2) \Theta(\theta) = 0 .\end{align*}
Since we do not want $\Theta$ to be $0$ since this will give the trivial
solution (i.e. $u \equiv 0$) which is not of interest to us. So the
boundary conditions give us

\begin{align*}R(1) = 0 \;\; \text{and}\;\; R(2) = 0 .\end{align*}

We will now solve the equation for $R$ which says

\begin{align*}r^2 R'' + r R' - \mu R = 0 . \,\end{align*} This is the Euler's equation and we
recall that we should look for solutions in the form

\begin{align*}R(r) = r^\alpha \,\end{align*} for an unknown constant $\alpha$ to be
determined. We compute that

\begin{align*}R' = \alpha r^{\alpha -1} \;\; \text{and} \;\; R'' = \alpha (\alpha -1) r^{\alpha -2} .\end{align*}
Substituting these into

\begin{align*}r^2 R'' + r R' - \mu R = 0 \,\end{align*} we get that

\begin{align*}\alpha (\alpha-1) + \alpha = \mu \,\end{align*} which after simplifying gives

\begin{align*}\alpha^2 = \mu  . \,\end{align*}

Here, the sign of $\mu$ will affect the form of the solution, so we have
three cases to consider. They are

\begin{description}
\itemsep1pt\parskip0pt\parsep0pt
\item[]
\textbf{case 1:} $\mu = - \lambda^2 < 0$

\textbf{case 2:} $\mu = 0$

\textbf{case 3:} $\mu = \lambda^2 > 0$
\end{description}

Further calculations show that \textbf{case 2} and \textbf{case 3} only
give trivial solutions. If you are not sure, you should try verifying
that yourself. For completeness of the solution, I will also include the
computation in the appendix of this solution.

Now, \textbf{case 1:} says that

\begin{align*}\alpha^2 = \mu = - \lambda^2 . \,\end{align*} This gives

\begin{align*}\alpha = \pm \lambda i .\end{align*} Recall that for the Euler's equation, if
$\alpha$ is in the form of $\alpha = a \pm bi$, the solution of the
Euler's equation can be written as

\begin{align*}R(r ) = C_1 r^a \cos(b \ln(r )) + C_2 r^a \sin(b \ln(r )) \,\end{align*} for
some arbitrary constants $C_1$ and $C_2$. For us, we have $a = 0$ and
$b = \lambda$, so our solution for $R$ is

\begin{align*}R(r ) = C_1 \cos(\lambda \ln(r )) + C_2 \sin(\lambda \ln(r )) . \,\end{align*}
Next, we need to match the boundary conditions
$R(1) = 0 \;\; \text{and} \;\; R(2) = 0 . \,$

\begin{align*}R(1) = 0 \Rightarrow 0 =  C_1 \cos(\lambda \underbrace{\ln(1)}_{= 0}) + C_2 \sin(\lambda \underbrace{\ln(1)}_{= 0}) = C_1 \underbrace{\cos(0)}_{=1} + C_2 \underbrace{\sin(0)}_{= 0} = C_1 .\end{align*}
Hence, $C_1 = 0$ and

\begin{align*}R(r ) = C_2 \sin(\lambda \ln(r )) . \,\end{align*} Now,

\begin{align*}R(2) = 0 \Rightarrow C_2 \sin(\lambda \ln(2)) = 0 .\end{align*} If $C_2 = 0$, we
will have the trivial solution. To get non-trivial solutions, we need

\begin{align*}\sin(\lambda \ln(2)) = 0 \Rightarrow \lambda \ln(2) = n \pi  \Rightarrow \lambda = \frac{n \pi}{\ln(2)} .\end{align*}
In other words, we have an infinite numbers of eigenvalues $\lambda_n$
give by

\begin{align*}\lambda_n = \frac{n \pi}{\ln(2)} \;\; \text{for} \;\; n = {\color{red}1} ,2,3, \cdots\end{align*}
with the corresponding eigenfunctions

\begin{align*}R_n(r) = C_n \sin(\lambda_n \ln(r)) . \,\end{align*}

Now, we will go back to solve the $\theta$ equation. Recall that we have
$\mu = - \lambda^2$ so the $\theta$ equation $- \Theta'' = \mu \Theta$
becomes

\begin{align*}
- \Theta'' &= - \lambda^2 \Theta\\
\Theta'' &= \lambda^2 \Theta \end{align*} which gives solutions of the form

\begin{align*}\Theta = A \cosh(\lambda \theta) + B \sinh(\lambda \theta) \,\end{align*} for
some arbitrary constants $A$ and $B$. Since we found that an infinite
number of $\lambda_n = \frac{n \pi}{\ln(2)}$, we have an infinite number
of $\Theta_n$ given by

\begin{align*}\Theta_n = A_n \cosh(\lambda_n \theta) + B_n \sinh(\lambda_n \theta) . \,\end{align*}

Putting everything together, we can express $u$ as

\begin{align*}u(r,t) = \sum_{n=1}^\infty C_n \sin(\lambda_n \ln(r)) \left(A_n \cosh(\lambda_n \theta) + B_n \sinh(\lambda_n \theta) \right) .\end{align*}
We can absorb the arbitrary constant $C_n$ into $A_n$ and $B_n$ to get

\begin{align*}u(r,t) = \sum_{n=1}^\infty \sin(\lambda_n \ln(r)) \left(A_n \cosh(\lambda_n \theta) + B_n \sinh(\lambda_n \theta) \right) .\end{align*}

Finally, we will use the other two boundary conditions $u(r,0) = 0$ and
$u(r,\frac{\pi}{2}) = f(r)$ to find $A_n$ and $B_n$.

\begin{align*}
&u(r,0) = 0 \,\\
&\sum_{n=1}^\infty \sin(\lambda_n \ln(r)) (A_n \underbrace{\cosh(0)}_{=1} + B_n \underbrace{\sinh(0)}_{=0} )  = 0 \\
&\sum_{n=1}^\infty A_n \sin(\lambda_n \ln(r))  = 0 .\\
&A_n = 0 \;\; \text{for each} \;\; n = 1,2,3,\cdots\end{align*}

Hence

\begin{align*}
u(r,t) &= \sum_{n=1}^\infty B_n \sin(\lambda_n \ln(r)) \sinh(\lambda_n \theta)\\
&=  \sum_{n=1}^\infty B_n \sin\left(\frac{n \pi}{\ln(2)} \ln(r)\right) \sinh\left(\lambda_n \theta\right)\end{align*} Finally, to find $B_n$, we use the last boundary
condition

\begin{align*}u\left(r,\frac{\pi}{2}\right) = \sin \left( \frac{2 \pi}{\ln(2)} \ln(r ) \right).\end{align*}
This boundary condition gives us that

\begin{align*}u\left(r,\frac{\pi}{2}\right) = \sum_{n=1}^\infty B_n \sin\left(\frac{n \pi}{\ln(2)} \ln(r)\right) \sinh\left(\lambda_n \frac{\pi}{2}\right) = \sin \left( \frac{2 \pi}{\ln(2)} \ln(r ) \right) .\end{align*}
If we expand out the summation, we see that

\begin{align*}
&B_1 \sin\left(\frac{\pi}{\ln(2)} \ln(r)\right) \sinh\left(\lambda_1 \frac{\pi}{2}\right)
+ {\color{blue} B_2 \sin\left(\frac{2 \pi}{\ln(2)} \ln(r)\right) \sinh\left(\lambda_2 \frac{\pi}{2}\right) }\\&+ B_3 \sin\left(\frac{3 \pi}{\ln(2)} \ln(r)\right) \sinh\left(\lambda_3 \frac{\pi}{2}\right)
+ \cdots = {\color{blue} \sin \left( \frac{2 \pi}{\ln(2)} \ln(r ) \right) }\end{align*} Here, we see that $n =2$ is the only term on the left
hand side that matches with the right hand side. Hence, we have

\begin{align*}B_n \sinh\left(\lambda_n \frac{\pi}{2}\right) = 0 \;\; \text{if} \;\; n \not = 2\end{align*}
and

\begin{align*}B_2 \sinh \left( \lambda_2 \frac{\pi}{2} \right) = 1\end{align*}

\begin{align*}\Rightarrow B_2 = \frac{1}{\sinh(\lambda_2 \frac{\pi}{2})} = \frac{1}{\sinh(\frac{2 \pi}{\ln(2)} \frac{\pi}{2})} .\end{align*}
In other words, the solution is

\begin{align*}u(r,\theta) = \frac{1}{\sinh \left( \frac{2 \pi}{\ln(2)} \frac{\pi}{2} \right) } \sin \left( \frac{2 \pi}{\ln(2)} \ln(r) \right) \sinh \left( \frac{2 \pi}{\ln(2)} \theta \right) .\end{align*}

 \textbf{Appendix:}

\emph{We will address two final questions in this appendix.}

\emph{Question 1: Refer to the solution above, why doesn't $\mu = 0$
lead to non-trivial solutions for the Euler's equation?}

\emph{Answer to question 1:} Suppose $\mu = 0$, then

\begin{align*}\alpha^2 = \mu \Rightarrow \alpha = 0 .\end{align*} The solution to the Euler's
equation is

\begin{align*}R(r ) = C_1 \ln(r ) + C_2  \,\end{align*} for some arbitrary constants $C_1$ and
$C_2$. The boundary condition $R(1) = 0$ implies

\begin{align*}R(1) = C_1 \underbrace{\ln(1)}_{= 0} + C_2 = 0 \Rightarrow C_2 = 0 .\end{align*}
So

\begin{align*}R(r ) = C_1 \ln(r ) . \,\end{align*} The boundary condition $R(2) = 0$ implies

\begin{align*}R(2) = C_1 \ln(2) = 0 \Rightarrow C_1 = 0 .\end{align*} Hence, we only get the
trivial solution.

\emph{Question 2: Refer to the solution above, why doesn't
$\mu = \lambda^2 > 0$ lead to non-trivial solutions for the Euler's
equation?}

\emph{Answer to question 2:} Suppose $\mu = \lambda^2 > 0$, then

\begin{align*}\alpha^2 = \mu \Rightarrow \alpha = \pm \lambda .\end{align*} The solution to
the Euler's equation is

\begin{align*}R(r ) = C_1 r^\lambda + C_2 r^{- \lambda}  \,\end{align*} for some arbitrary
constants $C_1$ and $C_2$. The boundary condition $R(1) = 0$ implies

\begin{align*}R(1) = C_1 + C_2 = 0 \Rightarrow C_1 = - C_2 .\end{align*} So

\begin{align*}R(r ) = C_1 r^\lambda - C_1 r^{-\lambda} . \,\end{align*} The boundary condition
$R(2) = 0$ implies

\begin{align*}R(2) = C_1 2^\lambda - C_1 2^{-\lambda} = 0 . \,\end{align*} If $C_1 = 0$, we
get a trivial solution, so suppose $C_1 \not = 0$, then we must have

\begin{align*}2^{\lambda} = 2^{-\lambda} \Rightarrow 2^{2 \lambda} = 1 \Rightarrow \lambda = 0 .\end{align*}
However, this contradicts with our original assumption that
$\lambda^2 > 0$.
hints:
Similar to question 2b of this exam, when using the method of separation
of variables, we would like to write $u$ as a product of two solutions
of a single variable. In question 2b, we wrote $u$ as
$u = \phi(x) \psi(t)$ but we need something slightly different this time
(\emph{because there is no $x$ or $t$ anywhere in the equation!}). How
should we write $u$ as a product of two solutions of a single variable
this time?
